newsitem.title: UK: ICI eyeing return to Eurobond market.
newsitem.headline: ICI eyeing return to Eurobond market.

text.p: Imperial Chemical Industries Plc said on Thursday it was watching international bond markets with a view to refinancing part of a massive loan taken out to buy Unilever's specialty chemicals division.
ICI announced the $8 billion purchase on Wednesday and, also, a $8.5 billion loan to finance it.
"We see it (loan) very much as a bridging facility," ICI finance director Alan Spall told Reuters.
"We will certainly look to the long-term debt markets. Work is being put in place."
Spall said ICI would consider all options. "We have not yet made any decisions."
ICI's debt burden will be reduced by asset disposals totalling around $5 billion over the next three years, leaving a balance of around $3 billion.
Its $8.5 billion loan, expected to be launched into syndication next week, is being jointly arranged by Goldman Sachs International, HSBC Markets and SBC Warburg.
A $2.0 billion loan taken out by ICI earlier this year was quickly taken up, dealers said.
"Before that they hadn't been in the market for 10 years. This new loan should go well," a loan market source said. "They are still a rare name in the market."
That rarity extends to the Eurobond market where ICI has just a few deals outstanding. They are a brace of 100 million stg bonds due 2003 and 2005, the last of which was launched in 1987.
ICI also has a $250 million deal due 2001 in the U.S. market.
Standard & Poor's Corp cut ICI's long-term credit rating to A- from A+ after news of the acquisition. Moody's Investor Service cut ICI to A3 from A2.
